body_html:
Hi Moldy,
The tensorflow core is written in cpp so tf is gcc compiled. However, I'm don't quite get what you mean with re-compiling, as this is not possible from the given binar and you'd need the source code anyway.

However, you could still try the last option I mentioned, to download cuda and cudnn manually and store them locally.
That is:

  1. create a folder /home/USERNAME/lib/
  2. download the cuda 8 installer and install it to /home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0
  3. download cudnn6 and extract the compressed file. There you'll find a folder structure that resembles the one found in /home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0. Copy the files to cuda-8.0, keeping the directory structure.
  4. Prepend the lib folder to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH, i.e.
    export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH. Or even better, put this line into your .bashrc so you don't have to repeat step 4 every time you want to use tensorflow.

If any of the methods work for you, please consider closing this issue.

Cheers,
Phil

Hi Moldy,
The tensorflow core is written in cpp so tf is gcc compiled. However, I'm don't quite get what you mean with re-compiling, as this is not possible from the given binar and you'd need the source code anyway.

However, you could still try the last option I mentioned, to download cuda and cudnn manually and store them locally.
That is:
1. create a folder /home/USERNAME/lib/
2. download the cuda 8 installer and install it to  /home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0
3. download cudnn6 and extract the compressed file. There you'll find a folder structure that resembles the one found in /home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0. Copy the files to cuda-8.0, keeping the directory structure.
4. Prepend the lib folder to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH, i.e.
` export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/USERNAME/lib/cuda-8.0/lib64:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH`. Or even better, put this line into your `.bashrc` so you don't have to repeat step 4 every time you want to use tensorflow.

If any of the methods work for you, please consider closing this issue.

Cheers,
Phil
